parts:
My objective is to make a csv of every single software **tool** mentioned in the Journal Internet Archaeology, issue by issue, paper by paper, year by year. 

# Tool definition
For our project, a software tool is any discrete piece of software—be it a program, script, or web application—that is developed or substantially modified by researchers to perform specific, research-oriented computational tasks. These tasks must involve active data processing, such as analysis, simulation, visualization, modeling, or automation, where input data is dynamically created, documented, transformed, or interpreted to generate meaningful results. In contrast, products whose primary function is to simply display, store, or promote static datasets—without offering mechanisms for active computational engagement—are excluded. 

In essence, a valid software tool for our purposes is one that not only supports research in archaeology or historical sciences but does so by actively collecting and/or processing data rather than merely serving as a generic data repository or static interface.


However, we need to take this step by step. 

Here is issue 1: https://intarch.ac.uk/journal/issue1/index.html
5: https://intarch.ac.uk/journal/issue5/index.html
10: https://intarch.ac.uk/journal/issue10/index.html

(extrapolate as you will)

# Task

For issues one through ten, please list EVERY SINGLE ARTICLE, then for EACH ARTICLE indicate if that article mentions or is about any software tools. A specific reference to a specific name is necessary here, because we will be looking at the lifecycle of software tools. So there must be sufficient specificity to know what tool they're mentioning or using. An indirect reference without names is insufficient. 

Then double-check that you've got the first 10 issues worth of articles. At this stage, no additional writing is required, just Article, url, tools mentioned.

We're going to be building on this dataset, slowly. While ultimately we're going to be going through all 70 issues (and looking at journals, we're keeping this specific request narrowly scoped.)

Feel free to use markdown tables or CSV output, whichever is more intelligible to future-prompts of o3. 

(Note well, that articles seem to be split across many sub-pages, so work and attention to detail will be necessary here.)

We need to have Title (Authors) | URL | Tools mentioned.

To ensure accuracy and completeness, could you confirm if you would like the extracted data in CSV format or presented in Markdown tables for easier readability? Also, would you like tools to be listed in a single column separated by commas, or would you prefer each tool to have its own column if multiple are mentioned in one article?

I wouldn't mind CSV, actually. We'll also need a column for Issue and for year. And tools can be multivariate right now, this is just our first pass.

Before we begin, can you synthesise and operationalise all of the above into a single reusable prompt, so that I may consistently point you at different parts of the dataset?

Understood! I will compile a CSV listing every article from issues 1 through 10 of *Internet Archaeology*, including article titles, URLs, publication year, issue number, and any software tools explicitly mentioned in each article. Only named tools that match the specified definition—software actively used for data analysis, modeling, visualization, or processing—will be included. 

I will conduct a thorough review to ensure all relevant articles from the first 10 issues are captured. I will notify you once the dataset is ready.

- **Issue number**
- **Year of publication**
- **Software tools mentioned** (only explicitly named tools that match the provided definition of research software)

### Definition of a Software Tool
A software tool for this dataset is defined as any program, script, or web application that has been developed or substantially modified by researchers for computational research tasks. These tasks should actively process, transform, or analyze data rather than simply store or display static content. Examples of valid computational tasks include:

- Data analysis
- Simulation
- Visualization
- Modeling
- Automation

**Excluded:** Generic repositories, static archives, or display-only platforms without interactive computational functions.

### Format Requirements
- Output should be a **CSV file** with the following columns:
  - **Title**
  - **Authors (if available)**

metadata.title: Internet Archaeol. 21. Stoyanovich. Index
metadata.text: In this article we present the Faceted Query Engine, a system developed at Columbia University under the aegis of the inter-disciplinary project Computational Tools for Modeling, Visualizing and Analyzing Historic and Archaeological Sites. Our system is based on novel Database Systems research that has been published in Computer Science venues (Ross and Janevski, 2004 and Ross et al., 2005). The goal of this article is to introduce our system to the target user audience - the archaeology community.

metadata.title: Internet Archaeol. 23. Murgatroyd. Technical considerations
metadata.text: Blender was chosen as the main software to be used for the modelling for a number of reasons. Firstly, Blender is free, which is especially important given the comparatively large cost of its competitors; Lightwave, Maya and 3D Studio Max. Its open source licence and ability to be easily expanded ensures a steady stream of updates created by the user community. Although its functionality and output are not yet directly comparable to other packages, it is catching up quickly and already contains enough functionality for the relatively simple demands this project placed on it. Blender's ability to interface with a variety of renderers also allows it more flexibility in

metadata.title: Internet Archaeol. 23. Charno. Summary
metadata.text: This article explores the use of Scalable Vector Graphics (SVG) and Ajax in the context of an archaeological project. An interactive image on the Web was developed for the Sikyon Survey Project using these technologies, applying the concepts and principles of Virtual Research Environments (VRE) to the design of this tool (although that aspect will not play a major role in this article). The Sikyon Survey Project and its needs are addressed to provide context for the interactive image, followed by a discussion about the development of the tool itself. Finally, this article looks at the developments of the Sikyon

metadata.text: data are discussed, and one approach to presenting such data in a GIS environment is explored. Spatial patterning is identified that suggests social identity and kinship were both important factors in the selection of dress and personal ornaments for burial.

metadata.async_task_title: Extract Software Tool Mentions from Internet Archaeology Issues 52-67

parts: Please provide an initial first prompt, which is comprehensive, for me to re-run this against a new journal. Would you like me to provide what I gave you the first time?

**Clarifying user request**

The user wants an initial comprehensive prompt to re-run against a new journal. It seems like they're asking if I should use the first prompt they provided. I could clarify if they want to provide that again, or I could just create a new comprehensive prompt based on what I know. I'll ask them for any specific details and move forward with that, to make sure I’m helping in the best way possible.

**Creating a comprehensive prompt**

The user wants a comprehensive first prompt to re-run against a new journal, so I'll focus on creating a clear message that states the requirements. This isn't about content, but rather about re-stating the original prompt in a modified way. I’ll include the objective of producing a CSV, with specific columns, and clarify the definitions. I'll also make sure to ask if they want to provide their initial instructions again or if they’d prefer me to proceed with the new prompt instead.

Below is an example of a comprehensive initial prompt you can use to re-run this process for a new journal. It mirrors the instructions we used previously for Internet Archaeology but is written in a generic way so you can swap in the new journal’s details (such as its URL, issue numbers, etc.):

---

**Initial Comprehensive Prompt for Extracting Software Tool Mentions from [New Journal]**

**Objective:**  
Extract a structured dataset from [New Journal] that documents every article (issue by issue) and identifies any explicitly named software tools mentioned in each article. These tools must be discrete pieces of software (programs, scripts, web applications) used by researchers for tasks such as data collection, preparation, analysis, simulation, visualization, modeling, or automation. Indirect or generic references are not acceptable.

**Data to Extract for Each Article:**  
- **Title:** The title of the article, enclosed in quotes.  
- **Authors:** The article’s authors, listed in a dedicated column.  
- **URL:** A direct link to the article.  
- **Issue Number:** The issue number in which the article appears.  
- **Year:** The publication year of the article.  
- **Tools Mentioned:** Explicitly named research software tools used for the relevant research tasks (multiple entries allowed, separated by semicolons).

**Output Format:**  
The final dataset should be output as a CSV file inside a code block. The columns must appear in this exact order:

```
"Title"	"Authors"	"URL"	"Issue Number"	"Year"	"Tools Mentioned"
```

**Additional Instructions:**  
- **No inline citations:** Avoid any extra markers or citation references within the data cells to prevent data corruption.  
- **Meticulous research:** Take as much time as needed to carefully review each article and verify the accuracy of tool mentions.  
- **Error Reporting:** If any errors or issues arise during the process, provide a separate error log outlining the encountered problems.  
- **Iterative Process:** This is a long-term, iterative project, so precision is prioritized over speed.  
- **Customization:** Replace [New Journal] with the actual journal name, and specify the issues (e.g., “issues 1–10” or “issues 31–67”) you wish to process.

**Example of How to Begin:**  
“Please process [New Journal] issues X through Y. For each article in these issues, extract the Title (in quotes), Authors, URL, Issue Number, Year, and any explicitly mentioned software tools that are used for data collection, preparation, analysis, simulation, visualization, modeling, or automation. Output the results as a CSV in a code block, with the columns in the following order:  
  
```
"Title"	"Authors"	"URL"	"Issue Number"	"Year"	"Tools Mentioned"
```  
  
If any errors occur, please provide an error log detailing the issues encountered.”

---

Would you like me to further customize or adjust any part of this prompt, or does this meet your needs for re-running the process on a new journal?
